p.b:
checked:
1. Part2. It is hard to differentiate from the plot a number like 0.7 from 0.6 etc. Because part 1 deals with stable eq. we can use something with unstable equil. I added an alternative part 2.
2. Part 6. WE do not need to check if it is true or false that the K of A is larger than B and the asked if it is true or false that K of B is larger than K of A
3. Part 6. WE can use the names of particles 1 and 2 as we are alreading using A and B to indicate points in the plot.
4. Part 7. I removed the 1.6 option because it is closed to 1.4

problem.p: The graph below shows the potential energy associated with a single conservative force F acting on a 0.5-kg particle moving along the x-direction. The potential energy values for some (but not all!) points are shown on the vertical axis of the graph. Use the graph to answer the questions below.
At what points is the object in stable equilibrium?

choicegroup.choice: There are no such points on the diagram
All points where the potential energy is greater than 1 Joule
All points where the potential energy is less than 1 Joule

problem.h3: Part 2. It is hard to read the scale. Not a good idea to put too many 0.xx numbers
problem.p: At what points is the object in stable equilibrium?
At what points is the object in unstable equilibrium?
At the instant when the particle is at point E its speed is zero. What is the particleâ€™s speed by the time it reaches point C?
The particle is launched to the left from point G. What minimum initial kinetic energy must the particle have in order to be able to reach point C?
Rank points D, E and F in the order of decreasing magnitude of the conservative force F acting on the particle.

Let us assume that the value of U does not depend on the mass of the particle. Two particles, 1 and 2, are released from point D with zero initial speed. Particle 1 has a mass of 0.5 kg; particle 2 has a mass of 2.0 kg. Both particles reach point C simultaneously. Which statements regarding the particles would be correct at the instant they reach point C?

optionresponse.p: Particle 2 must be released earlier than particle 1 in order for them to reach point C simultaneously.
Both particles would have the same potential energy.
Particle 1 would have greater kinetic energy than particle 2.
Particle 1 would have greater speed than particle 2.

problem.p: If points B and C are 2.0 meters apart, what is the approximate magnitude of force F acting on the particle between points B and C?
